title: What are the best qualities a teacher or librarian in an elementary school needs? - Quora

response.answer_text: I have been librarian (real, or at least titular) in three elementary schools, 30–40 years ago. I expect that the experience probably isn’t that different now, though. One thing you really need to have is flexibility. For librarians especially, you never know when you’ll come in and they’ll tell you your space will be used, that day or the next, for some community event (voting, for example). You’ll need to figure out, on the fly, what to do for the classes that were supposed to come in that day, and make sure that their “library day” isn’t wasted. You also need to recognize what kids can and can’t do. In one of my schools, kindergarten children were not allowed to check out library books. They badly wanted to, though, so I gave them permission check out one at a time for the first semester without taking them home - just using them in their classroom. We had an almost perfect record of on-time returns, so in the second semester I allowed them to take their books home, and they still kept their almost-perfect return record, better than any other class in the school. I have no idea what the next librarian did (I was only there for one year), but that worked very well, and, I hope, made the kids mindful library users for years to come. On the other hand, I did not allow them to check out encyclopedia volumes, because if one volume of the print set was lost, it couldn’t be replaced - you had to buy a whole new set. This was too much responsibility to place on a 5–11-year-old. You need a lot of patience. If you’re a classroom teacher, your patience is tried every day, and I have great admiration for people who can do this (I couldn’t!). As a librarian I had to be patient with the students because the library skills I was trying to teach them were not valued particularly by the school or the teachers, so they weren’t really supported by the teachers. I often had to tell them the same things over and over, and, being a very new librarian (or, as I mentioned, not a librarian yet at all), I didn’t always realize that I should cut them some slack. As other responders have mentioned, there are almost innumerable other qualities elementary educators need, but you asked for the “best,” and these are what came to mind. Thanks for the A-to-A!

22 Essential Qualities of a Super Teacher   1. Have clear objectives Create a plan. It is just like using a map while searching a treasure. It will ensure that you are following the correct path, andmoving in the right direction.   2. Have  a sense of purpose A teachers shapes 40 generations. You cannot give your 100% everyday. But on a scale of 1 to 10, aim to achieve, at least, 8.   3. Do not seek immediate feedback Teaching is just like gardening. It takes times, and some dirt, before you see bloomingflowers.   4. Know when to listen and when to ignore You cannot please every student. There is no point in listening and responding to each andevery point raised. However, it does not mean that you should pay no heed tothem either. Any point should be answered with,  “hmm… I shall see.” And if that point needs description say, “The other day youwere telling me to….”   5. Do not try to please everyone Prioritize When you are a teacher, you are the boss.   6. Act alone  You are the designer, actuator, judge, jury, andexecutioner. Create a transparent curriculum so that everyone can clearlysee what is happening.   7. Do not Keep the learning in the classroom Design lessons so that all learners and their families canwork together. Do not restrict yourself to what is mentioned in thecurriculum. Teach, what they can use in their life.   8. Do what you think is best for your students You are there for the students., Your job is to turn them into useful human beings. You should inspire them to lead a useful life.   9. Learners are books to be written Learn what is best for students. Assist them to discover new things on their own. Teach them to become an autodidact.   10. Teach them to believe in themselves and their abilities Prepare them for the future.   11. Alter your lesson plans accordingly Choose new units and lessons. Choose new authors. Choose new projects. Ask experts to give guest-lectures. You should not keep on teaching the same thing. Make your lesson plans more useful. Use authentic material (Newspaper cuttings etc)   12. Ask the students for new ideas Students know much better about what they want, and whatthey need. Use this knowledge of students to design your lesson plans. They after delivering the lesson, ask them what else do theywant. Ask them how can the delivered lesson plan be improved. Ask them to create a power point presentation of what theythink can improve your lesson plan.   13. Reflect Reflection is the most powerful of all improvementstrategies. Take a look back at what happened. Ask what learners liked the most.   14. Become the master of your subject Know your subject like the back of your hand. Be a continual learner of the methodology of “teaching”. Keep on learning new things about your subject. Stay hungry, stay foolish.   15. Think out of the box Milk technology Use facebook. Use WhatsApp. Create Power Point Presentations. Create audios and make it downloadable. Use every medium to facilitate learning.   16. Give them emotional support Students are human beings take the whole person into account. At times they will need your emotional support Connect on an emotional level Your level will rise from a teacher to a mentor   17. Praise authentically Catch students doing right things. Praise them then and there. Be authentic. You should know the true capability of your students. And if your student makes a genuine effort, he must bepraised.   18. Communicate with parents The parents of your students should know you. They must be able to contact you and vice-versa. You can use this communication to deliver the most by yourteaching.   19. Love your work / subject Do not teach, if you do not love teaching. Do not teach, if you do not love your subject.   20. Have a positive attitude Positivity breeds creativity. Even if they fail believe in their abilities. Tell them that is okay to fail. Negative energy sucks creativity   21. Sense Of Humor You cannot cultivate it You have it or you don’t. If you have it, teaching will be lot more easier   22. Adapt To Student Needs There is no panacea. What works for one, will kill another. You have to keep on changing to suit the needs of thestudent
